definition:
Let $\mathbb{T}^n=\mathbb{R}^n/(2\pi\mathbb{Z})^n$ be the
$n$-dimensional torus, let $\{\phi_k(x)\}_{k\in\mathbb{Z}^n}$ be an
orthonormal basis for $L^2(\mathbb{T}^n)$, and suppose that
$f(x)\in L^2(\mathbb{T}^n)$.

We can expand $f$ as a Fourier series

$$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{k\in\mathbb{Z}^n}\hat{f}(k)\phi_k,\end{aligned}$$

and we call the numbers $\hat{f}(k)$ the *Fourier coefficients* of $f$
with respect to the given basis. In particular, the Fourier series for
$f$ converges to $f$ in the $L^2$ norm.

The most basic incarnation of this is finding the Fourier coefficients
of a Riemann integrable function with respect to the orthonormal basis
given by the trigonometric functions:

Let $f$ be a Riemann integrable function from $[-\pi,\pi]$ to
$\mathbb{R}$. Then the numbers $$\begin{aligned}
a_0 &= \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}f(x)dx,\\
a_n &= \frac{1}{\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}f(x)\cos(nx)dx,\\
b_n &= \frac{1}{\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}f(x)\sin(nx)dx.\end{aligned}$$ are
called the Fourier coefficients of the function $f.$

The above can be repeated for a Lebesgue-integrable function $f$ if we
use the Lebesgue integral in place of the Riemann integral. This is the
usual setting for modern Fourier analysis.

The trigonometric series
$$a_0 + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(a_n\cos(nx)+b_n\sin(nx))$$ is called the
trigonometric series of the function $f$, or Fourier series of the
function $f.$
